p: The essential oil of S. officinalis subsp. lavandulifolia, after a single oral dose of 50 μL, has shown to improve cognitive function in healthy humans compared to placebo, specially the performance of secondary memory and attention tasks (Kennedy et al., 2011). This effect has been mainly related to the inhibition of acetylcholinesterase by the oil, 1,8-cineol followed by α-pinene being the most active constituents (Perry et al., 2003; Kennedy et al., 2011). Taking in account the similarity in composition with the essential oil of S. blancoana subsp. mariolensis, which is particularly rich in 1,8-cineol, the effect on cognitive function could also be expected from the oil of this species.
